The only thing that kept it from getting 5 stars.  Parking cost $$ for valet.(everywhere I go in Nashville there is no charge for valet even downtown) also you have to have a cc to make a reservation, also the only place I have had to do that.(not a fan of either)

My husband and I have been longtime fans of Green Pheasant and Two Ten and recently took some friends. For context most of us are gluten free and dairy free and some of us avoid red meat.

The new layout of the menu made it super easy to make great choices. Our server, who was friendly and attentive, didn't seem to know what was and was not compliant but did make sure to talk to the kitchen for us and made a great sake recommendation. 

Outside our normal faves (Tebasaki Gyoza, tuna tartare and wedges), we loved the new cold additions, including the yellowtail sashimi. And the fries were great!

Fun vibe and great meal. It's our go to for whenever we are downtown.

Had lunch here for the 3rd time yesterday and highly recommend the experience.  It is a perfect place for a quiet business lunch.  Very comfortable seating, and great, unobtrusive service.  And for me, the food has to be great & interesting, and Green Pheasant scores highly here too.  I have had the Karaage (Japanese fried chicken) each time.  It melts in your mouth, and even though it looks like chicken nuggets, the flavor is tremendous.  I recommend eating it while still hot, as it just tastes better before it cools.  I have also had the gyoza, yakisoba, and tuna tartare.  All were very good.  Small plates is the way I like to eat, and this place fits nicely into that ability to try different things, and not get too full at mid-day.  I need to get here for dinner next.

$129.77 later without tax or tip and 12,977% worth the money spent. Yes, baby, yes! Can I get an hallelujah?! I am screaming at the top of my lungs for The Green Pheasant. Alas, I have found my date night spot. Now, if only I had a date to take with me!

That was pretty exciting first paragraph, wasn't it? The breakdown is pretty clear. When you arrive, valet the car with the restaurant. Just do it and quit groaning at the suggestion. This will make your life a whole lot easier for a stress-free starter to your date. Go to the hostess desk where they will seat you for your reservation that you made 2 weeks ago. As they take you to your table, observe the ambiance. Will they take you to the upstairs with the quirky bathrooms? Will they take you to the main dining room where there is a central bar to people watch or are they going to take you to your private dining room with the awesome wallpaper of CCTV cameras and roses? Yes, you read that right. If you are able, take some photos in there because the wallpaper is totally worth a photo of. Most of the restaurant should find itself in a covershoot in Nashville Scene. Who doesn't love green and red velvet everywhere!?

Now that you're seated, take it all in. Check out the menu and inhale all of the quirky offerings on the menu. But before ordering food, get your sake order in and prepare for a toast! You can get that unique cocktail you were eyeing in the next round. This round is about sharing the moment you realized you're about to have one of the best damn dining experiences in Nashville. Kanpai! ('Cheers' in Japanese)

You've looked over the menu and you're going to order 4-5 items between you and your dining companion. They offer everything from vegetarian to what I'd consider a very large unsightly fish on a plate ready for consumption. I don't like whole fish, but the table next to us certainly did! Whatever you palette wishes is Green Pheasant's command.

The experience exceeds just the dining portion. Let's talk service. Carlos was exceptional. Beyond words, topnotch, never missed a beat, glowing service. He was hospitable, prompt, and very nurturing to our table. He never hoovered and we never had to ask for anything. He was like a genie who appeared when I had a fleeting thought of needing a beverage or another glass of water. We also appreciated his knowledge of the cuisine and his mindfulness of our spice-level tolerance. We ordered based on his recommendations and we loved every last thing he suggested.

After 2.5 hours of eating and drinking, it is time to go. Time to wrap up and get going. But, you do not exit without leaving a gigantic tip for the awesome server you just had, and you do not omit grabbing a couple of photos of yourself with your dining partner to capture the experience that will be ingrained in your culinary memory for a life time. Bask in the moment while you can. You'll return soon, but in the meantime, enjoy the moment at this moment.

Have fun? I know I did. Check it out and do it soon!

The Green Pheasant was probably one of the worst dining experiences I've had to date and I dine out frequently, globally, so I feel I've got decent perspective. It started with check-in and seating. When we arrived, the two hosts, clearly flustered and whom I felt badly for if I'm being honest as they were overwhelmed, were arguing with each other over a table that had been somehow mis-seated. They audibly (and in front of other guests) tried to work this issue out but meanwhile let other guests linger in the very small waiting area in the front without explanation. 

After checking-in at 8:10pm for our 8:15pm reservation, we were told our table wasn't yet ready and when we asked approximately how long the wait would be, we were told "tables are just lingering, so please head to the bar." Anyone who's worked in the Industry understands occasionally this happens after check drops, especially on weekends, however to my surprise upon walking in the dining room I observe multiple open tables/tables that need to be serviced and flipped. 

We are forced to sit at the bar (where the service was really less than stellar and/or quick) until 8:45pm and I'm convinced the only reason we got a table is because a member of our party kept continually checking in with the host to inquire about our reservation. 

Once seated (and starving), we received a brief apology from our server and he noted that this "happens around the 8pm reservation time sometimes," so it seems like this seating delay is a common problem Green Pheasant is aware of. We immediately ordered some dishes because we were starving. Since the first two were raw foods, they were delivered to us fairly quickly. The rest took FOREVER. We were told the kitchen was very backed up and they'd come out as they were ready. To say this was frustrating after our wait to be seated was an understatement. 

I observed a manager on the restaurant floor in our area only once throughout the night. He never did a table touch to ask about or experience in general, or to apologize for the wait for the table or food delays. There was no good faith gesture of any sort or acknowledgement from the restaurant regarding our experience beyond the very brief apology from our server, who obviously doesn't control the kitchen volume. 

The food was decent but to be honest, I was so hungry by the time any food came out, I would have eaten just about anything. 

To summarize, I would never return to The Green Pheasant and am baffled by the positive reviews of this restaurant given what I experienced, observed, and discussed with fellow diners while at the restaurant. What an extremely disappointing (and pricey!) experience.

Easily one of the best restaurants I've been to in my life. They lobster corn dumplings are single bites of some of the best food you could ever have. Their chicken, shrimp wing is incredible. I dream of eating here again.

Love the food and atmosphere at Green Pheasant. There is some great variety to the menu, as well as the different sections of the restaurant. I'm excited to try some of the other options next time we visit. Definitely try one of the dumpling options if it's your first time.

Went around noon on a Monday and there were only about 4-5 tables having lunch. Sat at the bar - ordered the greens as an appetizer and the moonfish skewers. Very clean flavors, definitely on the subtle seasoning side - but all well prepared and healthy.

We had a large group of 11 people, so we were able to try almost everything on the menu, and I would definitely eat it all again. Some standouts: sunomono, broccolini, curry udon, tebasaki gyoza (so crispy!!), ikinari steak. Everything was so flavorful and we were all so pleased with everything by the end of our meal. Leave room for dessert! It's definitely worth it! And on top of a delicious meal, the restaurant is gorgeous!

This place was terrible!
The ambience was great. 
But!!!
Our waiter had a lumberjack flannel shirt with a baseball cap.
Our appetizer was a smoked Bok Choi that was extremely watery and had a terrible taste.
Also had the spicy crab noodle dish which was very small with mediocre taste.
The Sui Gyoza we are very small and handle very little flavor.
You have to pay your bill at the tour and we had to actually find somebody at the cash register.
Very pretentious and expensive with small portions.
Service was not the best for the price of the tab, but a pretty interesting place to go to! The inside looks amazing

This place is delicious in the way it taste and looks! The menu is always changing which is fun. I went with a group of girls and we ordered almost everything on the menu. This place is all tapas so if you are hungry and want to eat quickly you'll have to be patient. It's best when you can just enjoy the food slowly. There were moments that I tried something and I wanted to stop time- it was a burst of flavor in my mouth. My favorites are the tuna tartare and the lobster dumplings. Order a little at a time and see where the night takes you!

Most of Nashville's new restaurants, while quite good, are not that different from each other.  The Green Pheasant is different.  Japanese-  But far from your average (or even above average) sushi restaurant.  Expect truly interesting, even strange, dishes with SUPERB flavors.  Subtle or powerful depending, light or rich, depending on the dish-  the food here is truly remarkable.  And, you will find dishes you likely have never experienced, (but are worth the try!!) as well as some to please the less than adventurous eater.  If you have never had Japanese wagyu beef -  it's is rare to find it in the US and is considered some of the best beef available in the world.  I'm not a sake fan-  (even cold sake, which is THE thing now) but they have trained sake specialists to help you select!  The wait staff was super knowledgeable, friendly, and helpful.  
The decor and atmosphere is wonderful, with tables having a good amount of space between them so there is some privacy.  In short-  try this place!!!!

I want to make sure everyone knows just how good and accommodating the service was here first and foremost and not to take attention away from how great the food was.  We made reservations for 8:30 and our table was a little behind so we headed to the bar for a pre dinner cocktail.  Sake on tap is pretty cool and in my opinion a great drink to order before and with dinner here.  My date had forgotten her id....on her bday...and after she returned the bartender bought her a drink.  Didn't have to just did it out of kindness and made sure to get it to our table.  Thank you Mike!  The hostesses at the door kept us informed and were very polite when our table became ready.  Our seat was in one of the crushed velvet booths and was comfortable and could easily sit 4 just as comfortably to share all of our dishes with.  The food is served tapas style and arrives quickly to your table.  Our server was well informed about the menu and all employees were eager to share personal menu favorites as well as popular patron choices.  The okonomiyaki, spicy crab noodle and ikinari steak was our favorites out of the 4 plates we ordered and plenty for 2 people.  The fourth dish was the tebasaki gyoza not my style but was still very flavorful and with a crispy outer crunch.  I was surprised at the check expecting it to be more for a night out but was very affordable for a beginning of a fun date night!  We are excited to go back and try everything on the menu and I would love to come back for the lunch menu.  

A few tips:
1. Don't eat all day before you go,  you will want the extra room!
2. Everything is unique and delicious don't be afraid to explore!
3. The miso butter on the steak is very good,  we mixed it into the hot      plate with everything but next time might try it on the side for dipping.  It wasn't bad but I think we overpowered the other flavors with all the butter.
4. Repeat, don't eat before you go!
5. Bonus Ascend is right across the street.

This was our final dinner in Nashville.  We didn't have this one planned out, rather looked at online reviews for nice Asian because we had already had so much heavy, fried cuisine.  This place was a gem!

I called ahead for a reservation but they were booked up for most of the night.   I was told we could sit at the bar and it would be best to come early.   We actually arrived before their dinner hours began, so we sat at the bar and ordered from their small plates.  

Mike was very friendly, helpful, and welcoming.  He concocted a great non-alcoholic drink for me, which I ordered a few of over the course of our meal!   I can't remember exactly what it was, I believe it was made of cranberry juice, soda water, and a generous sprig of rosemary (picture attached).

We started with the edamame, yaki gyoza (pheasant dumplings), tuna tartare, and lobster shumai (lobster and corn dumplings).  Everything was nicely plated and tasted wonderful.

Next up were the famed spicy crab noodles.  Upon arrival of this dish, we quickly realized: a) that it was so good that we had to order another, b) that it was so good that my spouse was going to eat it all so we had to order another, and c) that it was so good that I wasn't going to want to share the dish with my spouse, so we had to order another!  So, we immediately ordered another!   

Also--interesting find--the toilet seats were heated!  

This is a very unique establishment and we were glad to have the opportunity to visit it!   We were happy to find such a friendly place with fresh ingredients and very unique selections for our last big meal in Nashville!

Unreal and incredible food. We did 4 apps and the skirt steak along with the yakisoba. Flavor in everything was perfect. I wished we weren't in a hotel for the week and we could have taken left overs! 
Highly recommend.

Went to this place a few days ago for lunch with coworkers, as our office is right up the block. Couldn't be more disappointed. For the price, it was atrocious. Paid $14 for a rice and chicken dish, which had absolutely no flavor at all. Had to douse it in chill oil and soy sauce to get any flavor. Worse part they charged us for the soy sauce, chill oil, and spices ($2-3 each). If you're in the mood for a flavorless $20 lunch, come here. Otherwise, keep walking. Can't believe I'm saying this, but even the food in a Broadway honky tonk is better than this sad excuse for a restaurant.

I went with a group of ten ladies on z weeknight. I ordered the chicken small plate at $22. I disliked it and asked the waitress to box the remaining in case somebody in my household would like it. Half the table wanted to share plates and half the table ordered a solo plate for themselves because we did not want a large meal. The restaurant was not able to accommodate this when it came time to billing. So those of us that ordered one item as an entree were not able to get our own check. Nobody in my household like the chicken dish so not a good evening for dining out. The valet parking was a fixed $12 per car.  We were in a beautifully decorated private room.  The group was largely not overwhelmed with the flavors and their menu selections.

The Green Pheasant is a fantastic addition to the Nashville food scene! 

Food: We had the Kinoko Mushroom Medley and Dandan Shishito Peppers -- both were fantastic. The broth/sauce in the mushroom dish was perhaps one of the best things I've eaten this year.

Bar Menu: Good selection of sake and other liquors. The staff are knowledgable and willing to help you find a sake that suits your palate. We had the whiskey barrel-aged sake which was served in a jar that you open yourself -- fun! Bartender Mike was friendly and remembered me the next time I came in.

Ambiance: The mid-century vibe meshed with Japanese culture seems a bit odd when you break it all down into individual parts but together, as a whole, the place is totally Nashville and just works. The decor is hip and on-trend while still sending out a warm and inviting ambiance. I LOVE the die-cut booth dividers which still let in light but create a nice division of space. 

My only wish would be for a more diverse Happy Hour drink menu, which currently features sake and beer. How about bubbly and whiskey?

All in all, The Green Pheasant is a wonderful date night, after-work light bites, or a classy kick-start to your Broadway tourist experience.

We decided to spend our pre-Thanksgiving Tuesday at the Green Pheasant last night. We were not disappointed! The space is sleek, cool and comfortable. The nonstop "house" music was a bit much, and made it somewhat hard to hear dinner conversation, but we understood the vibe that they were shooting for and took it all in stride. The menu is a fantastic mix of classic Japanese izakaya dishes with some larger plates that are great for sharing. I'm not a big fan of menus that list the name of the dish followed by all of the ingredients without an actual description of the preparation, but our server was very familiar with the menu and talked us through everything. We had two of their craft cocktails; they were spot on perfect. Each was a great mix of sweet, sour, bitter and refreshing. 
We ordered Dan Dan Shishito peppers; very reminiscent of Dan Dan Mian,  without the heaviness of the noodles. A great started. That was followed by lobster and spot prawn shu mai; unlike many restaurant dishes that claim to feature lobster, the succulent crustacean was very present in this one. Then a riff on okonomiyaki; a hash brown pancake with traditional okonomiyaki toppings and sauces. It was like an asian latke; perfect for this time of year. We finished with the whole trout, fried and served with thinly sliced cucumbers, asian slaw and steamed buns. The trout was cooked perfectly; it was silky and juicy. One thing to note; for a restaurant that features a sharing menu, a puzzling number of items came out in odd numbers. 5 shu mai, three steamed buns with the trout; Management-how about 6 shu mai and 4 steamed buns so a pair of enthusiastic and hungry diners don't have to fight over the "odd bun out"? 

In any event, the food was fabulous, and the bill for the meal, with 2 craft cocktails, came out to less than $100. Do yourself a favor and get to the Green Pheasant early and often!

It's rare to have a perfect experience at even the best restaurants but that exactly what we had last night.  Service was effective. The restaurant was comfortable and interesting.  The food was outstanding.  Lobster shomai was so memorable.  The wagyu beef was perfectly cooked and presented and the spicy crab noodles were equally great.  We are from Atlanta so can't get back anytime soon but we will be there again at some point.  It's worth the trip!

More like 3.5 stars but because of good service I'm upgrading. Went in for dinner and ordered the Japanese pickles and Chirashi.
While the pickles were ok, I was disappointed with the quality of fish. Some small and bigger cut pieces to start off, but the moon fish was really chewy and I had to tell them about it.
They offered to redo the entire dish only to come back with the same issues. Sounds like the chef doesn't care that some fish cuts shouldn't be served like this.
Anyways, for dessert I had their tempura chocolate cake: rich, sweet and not too oily, so it was quite good.
Overall not impressed.

I do not understand the 5 star reviews. We really wanted to love this place. The restaurant is beautiful and the concept is admirable. However the food is very disappointing. 
We started with shishito peppers which turned out to be the best of what we had tonight. Good but not so great I would return just for that. We had the tuna tartar which had a decent flavor but was warm and chopped up so much that one would wonder if they were trying to hide that they were using poor quality tuna. Imagine room temperature cat food on top of warm rice cake. The whole thing did not work. 
Then to the entree. The steak was good but salty. The spicy crab pasta which is their signature dish came out cold and way after the steak. When we told the waiter it was cool, we were told it was because the noodle was rinsed and would never be piping hot. I'm sorry but a bit warmer than cold doesn't cut it. This was also very salty and I was told it was because I asked for spicy and they added chili sauce. Really?  The chef does not know how to make things spicier without making it so salty you can't eat?  So to save time and by this point my husband had already finished his steak so I asked for some plain hot noodles to be added. 
They brought some dumplings while waiting which was a nice touch but please don't bother ordering. They are less than tasty. 

Finally the noodles came out and they added garlic butter which made the plain pasta salty again. JAPANESE FOOD DOES NOT HAVE TO BE SALTY. 
By now we were ready to get out of this pretentious place. The bill came out and they had charged us 14 for the noodles. So they charged 26 for salty lukewarm entree that was not edible as it was, then charged 14 more for what I had hoped to be warm plain noodles. So basically we were asked to pay 40 for a mediocre dish. We complained and they took it off the bill but that should have never happened. 

My prediction is that the place would not survive if they do not improve the quality of their food. You cannot survive on looks and cool vibe alone.

I applaud you, Green Pheasant. I'm not sure to whom I am applauding--their interior designers, the servers, the chefs, but everyone gets a big high five. This was one of the best dining experiences I've had in Nashville. The meal was exceptional from start to finish. 

The service--
We had made a reservation on Resy through their website and we were seated promptly on-time. When we were seated we were brought warm towels to wipe our hands. Our server greeted us and was very accommodating. She was the best! 

The ambiance--
There was a slight Asian flavor to the decor but everything was very modern. Some of the seating had plush booths and some were tables. There was a center bar for people who just came to get drinks. The restrooms were very clean and to our amusement and delight they had  Japanese toilets which had a seat warming feature. 

The food--
Their menu consists of a cold section and a hot section. There aren't appetizers but the menu is mostly small plates and then towards the bottom of the menu the plates get larger. Our server went into the most detail of the menu of any server that I've ever had. It was great. She highlighted her favorite dishes but gave an explanation of how the dishes were prepared so we knew what to expect. We ordered: 
-Spicy crab noodles: buttered noodles with crab meat. My favorite, but apparently also most people's favorite since our server has said that every table will likely have one order of these. 
-Tebasaki gyoza: This dish blew my mind. Instead of the chicken stuffed into a traditional gyoza dumpling, the gyoza is stuffed into the chicken wing. It is deboned except for the end of the wing so you are getting a crispy chicken with the filling of the gyoza in the center. 
-Kinoko: These were different kinds of mushroom with Parmesan. They had such a great earthy flavor and a light broth.
-Broccolini with corn bread and rock shrimp: This dish seemed like an interesting pairing but everything worked together. The sauce for the broccolini was delicious and the rock shrimp had a different seasoning which worked together
-Wedges: This was the one dish I could have done without, but it was still good. The salad was served on skewers with dressing and shaved carrots. 

The ambiance, the service and the food was all amazing. High marks for all. The dinner was very memorable and enjoyable. I'll be looking forward to my next visit here!

Way pricier than I thought it would be and some of the front staff were not pleasant, but the food is absolutely amazing and so is the ambiance. I would definitely return for a drink and an appetizer or something but not again when I'm starving because I'm just too poor to fork out a few hundred dollars for a meal with one other person. Portions are very small.

This place was excellent. I'm not usually a huge fan of small plates, but the portions were reasonable for the price and quality. Everything was absolutely scrumptious. The atmosphere and service were top notch. It's a great place to go with a small group. 

I highly recommend the lobster shumai and filet mignon with miso butter. Yum!!!

A bit of a miss. It started prior to visit with excessive text reminders of my reservation to then arrive and find the restaurant nearly empty, only 4 tables occupied. Greeting felt a little pretentious. Fortunately, the waiter was friendly and had good recommendations for sake and food. The walu dish was incredible, served sashimi style with bergamot ponzu and radish oroshi. Light and fresh! I followed that with a fan favorite, spicy crab noodles. This dish was also delicious. Surprisingly, the kinoko mushroom dish was a big disappointment. The broth gave the dish a dirty taste. I only took a few bites. The server that cleared my table saw the full dish and didn't show any concern that it wasn't eaten. I've had better dining experiences in Nashville.

This place is a little further from all the action of broadway but well worth the extra blocks. Small plates allow for multiple types of delicious food. Everything we ate was fantastic (Japanese waygu, pheasant gyoza, crab noodles, chicken wings, etc). And they have. Nice selection of alcoholic choices as well.

Amazing flavors!! We love unique places and we weren't disappointed. Service was great, he coursed everything out perfectly, yummy cocktails and delicious food made our last night in Nashville even more memorable. Highly recommend the spicy crab noodles, kinoko and the salmon.

We had an outstanding meal at the Green Pheasant on Tuesday night this week. I went in with high expectations and they were exceeded. 

We started with the Broccolini (shrimp, crumbled corn bread, and broccolini). The broccolini was bright and crisp-tender. The shrimp were perfectly cooked. It seemed like an unusual combination of flavors and textures but it totally worked. 

We also tried the Shumai starter (dumplings filled with lobster and shrimp and sitting in a ponzu sauce). They may have been my favorite dish of the night. Perfection. 

For our larger plates, my husband and I shared the ora king salmon and the spicy crab noodle. The salmon was outstanding. It had a crispy charred side that tasted like cotton candy (in the best possible way). The salmon was served with bok choy which was perfectly cooked and paired nicely with the salmon. The spicy crab noodles were absurdly delicious as well. We fought over every last bite. 

As a party of two, this ended up being the perfect amount of food for us. We were full when we left, but not stuffed. 

Green Pheasant is great for date night or girls' night out. It's also perfectly positioned if you are headed to Ascend. We were on our way to a concert and could literally see the entrance gate from our table.

A pretty space in the heart of downtown.  Food was interesting but did not blow me away. Service was excellent, and the Japanese whiskey drinks were great. Even with plentiful ordering of shared entrees and dessert, I found myself hungry soon after dinner. A return visit unlikely.
Service and atmosphere are great but the food was awful! We ordered several cold/hot options and all left hungry and disappointed. Definitely not worth the price!

I don't get the hype. We arrived for our reservation right on time and were sat immediately. Waited... and waited. Told the hostess no one had come by after 15 mins. Finally a server arrives and we are all set to order. We get the chicken wing "dumplings", lobster dumplings, edamame, salmon dinner and infamous spicy crab noodles. Chicken wings were certainly creative just not tasty - all it tasted like was fryer. Lobster dumplings were too buttery and we had about one each and left the rest. Edamame was fine, steamed with salt, nothing distinctive. Salmon was very tasty but almost raw. The noodles everyone raves about were good,  not as spicy as I would have loved. All and all a mediocre experience. Too many choices in Nashville to ever go back.

So I had the kushiyaki for lunch (pictured).  It was amazing.  The grilled mushroom, eggplant and avocado was very tasty, cooked just enough and was the perfect proportion.  

As for the sides, the miso soup was good as expected.  The kimchi was perfect.  Some spice and proportioned perfectly.  

The ambience and this place is really special. It is quite relaxing.  There is something artistic about the entire place, including the preparation.  I will visit this restaurant again.

It's nice to have the option to eat at an Asian restaurant in SoBro however the menu is limited. You can order from the Cold and Hot menu but there aren't a lot of choices on either one. The food is expensive and our dishes were bland. The food and drinks are expensive. The food arrived at our table without thought, so we received a hot dish at the same time that we received a cold dish. We stood at the bar another day and the hostess kept badgering our group to move even though the restaurant was empty at that time. She was fairly obnoxious. If a bar doesn't want patrons to stand it can provide more seats or extend the bar seating into the restaurant area. The restaurant makes more profit from its drinks than its food in any case. On the bright side, the commodes are wonderful and are like the commodes one finds in Japan. Perhaps patrons can imbibe there....
Amazing. The service was great. The food was spectacular. We tried about 5 plates and the brownie dessert. Everything was delicious.

Eating here was by far one of the best dining experiences I've ever had. I knew that the minds behind Two Ten Jack next creation would be even more incredible. The food was truly magical. It was really hard to keep from ordering more and more food.

Picked this place for my best friends birthday dinner because of its sister restaurant Two Ten Jacks reputation. It's UNBELIEVABLE! The ambiance is, as my friend said, "the absolute cutest" with shiny wallpaper and heated toilet seats. And the food--goodness gracious, the food. We went nuts with the appetizers. Lobster shu Mai, pheasant dumplings, moon fish ceviche, oh my! The entree is one of the best I've had in a while. If you don't try the wagyu beef and spicy crab noodles, you're not really a good fan. Don't worry, I'll be back.

This place is fairly new so if you want to get in on the weekends make sure to make reservations. The restaurant itself is beautiful!!! More like an intimate romantic setting. My table each ordered something different and all our food was good. It is more of a smaller dish but of you order a couple things to share you will get full. Our server was really attentive and checked on us often and made sure we had everything we needed at all times. Definitely have to come back and try the other dishes.

4.5 stars. I had dinner last night here for my birthday and it was delicious! I would recommend making a reservation though, especially on the weekend. Our reservation was at 8:30 and our table wasn't quite ready yet when we got there so we got a drink at the bar while we waited. Our table was ready about 15 minutes later at 8:45, but it was worth the wait because they seated us on the first level at a little booth with plush velvet, super comfortable!

Side note: do not forget your ID especially on your birthday! I'm embarrassed to say that I made this mistake (I had switched purses, it's a girl thing) so I had to run home to grab it. So it was fine that our table wasn't ready right away. And the bartender was so nice and felt bad that I had to run home he ended up buying my first drink! I believe his name was Mike, super friendly and great bartender. 

There was just two of us and we ordered 5 dishes which was the right amount of food for us. They are tapas style and made for sharing it seems. Our food also came out pretty quick. We were full by the end but not busting at the seams. They bring each dish out as they are ready instead of bringing it all out at once which I like so you're not waiting for a long time to eat. 

We started off with the wedge salad. It was skewers of lettuce with a ginger dressing on top. Fresh and tasty, although maybe a little pricey. 

Next we had the Okonomiyaki which was delicious. It was a crispy savory hashbrown type pancake with sauces and toppings on top. Highly recommend!

Then we had the Tebasaki Gyoza. Do not be fooled by the name, it is not a gyoza. It is actually a deboned chicken wing stuffed with a mixture of shrimp. There is a chili sauce for dipping. This is probably unusual for most people. The outer crust was super crispy which I loved. It had also come out super fresh and hot. A sign it was made to order and hadn't been sitting for a while. My boyfriend was so so about this dish, but I really liked it. So it depends on the person. 

After came the spicy crab noodles which had come highly recommended. It was very saucy and rich. It wasn't as spicy as I thought it would be although there was a good amount of crab in there. I would recommend mixing it up before you start as all of our crab and stuff had kind of settled towards the bottom. I didn't end up loving this dish as I had thought I would. The flavors were a bit muddled and maybe a little too rich for me. 

Lastly, we had the ikinari steak. It's American skirt steak on a bed of sweet corn and onions with a generous scoop of the miso butter. It was cooked perfectly medium rare and came out on a sizzling skillet. So for those who don't like their meet too rare, it does continue to cook a bit after it comes out. The steak was super tender and had a sauce on top. For me it could have had a little less sauce so the steak could shine, but still delicious nevertheless. It was a little difficult to eat the corn with chopsticks though haha. I could have asked for other utensils, but I didn't want to be "that person."

Overall it was a great experience. The decor instead was beautiful, with a mix of mid century furniture and more luxurious touches like the velvet booths. Everyone we encountered was friendly and our server was great, very knowledgeable and nice. Would definitely come back to try the other dishes.

Great restaurant with EXCELLENT service. Our girl Lauren V was top notch. Little things make a big difference. They automatically put us in a booth with our Resy reservation. The staff inputs drink orders on iPads so they'll be ready ASAP, before they're even done explaining the menu. I appreciated how our food recommendations were not automatically the most expensive item. The staff was even thoughtful about recommending clean plates and new chopsticks. Food was excellent, but the service was what sealed the deal. Will definitely be back!

The start to our experience here was not great. I called ahead to find out if there was valet at the restaurant in which I was told yes there is. This was great bc we didn't have to pay for uber etc. so when we arrive to the valet stand there is no one in sight and a line of cars parked on the street. Essentially no where legally for us to park to wait for the valet. When we see the valet run up I got out to hand him my keys hoping he knows better than I where we can park our car and he can take it from there. He snaps at us he's swamped and that we need to legally park and to pay a $12 fee for the valet before he can help us. I understand he is working alone on a Saturday night but the attitude was unnecessary. We ended up parking in a garage right down the street and The green pheasant validated it, I feel for the guy but he could have been more pleasant and apologetic. Two people working the stand could probably solve the problem. Then when I arrive my friends I'm meeting are waiting at the bar explained we couldn't be seated until everyone arrived. They'd been waiting at least ten minutes bc of the valet situation and we let the hostess know we are all there and she forgot about us. We reminded her promptly but we didn't feel like we got a warm welcome. Everything was exponentially better once we were seated and welcomed by our waitress Lauren, who goes by L2. She was warm and informative. All the food we ordered was delicious. If I were to rate this place based on the food and Lauren's service alone it would be 5+stars! I definitely would recommend this place to friends but I would tell them either uber or skip the valet all together and park in the garage and have the restaurant validate the parking. The crab noodles were amazing, but there wasn't a thing I tasted I didn't like!

Way too bougie with everything. Spent $200, left hungry and stopped at McDonalds on the way home. I get it's tapas style and to share but these plates were 1 bite per person.

Wedges were just a normal salad just on a tooth pick.
Chicken wings only has 3. Charged $5 for 1 additional so that each person in the party could have a bite.
Gyoza was decent but nothing great

Would not recommend

TGP has two stand-out features: Ambience (Read date night!) and rare ingredients. 

Compared to other haute cuisine restaurants, there are few of this grandeur. It is mid-century, dimly lit, with grand emerald green velvet seats and walls of the same color. It's going to give date night spots in town a run for the money. The vibe is upscale with house lounge music (loud and could be toned down). Plus, the serving ware is gorgeous. The dish added to the beauty of the dish. (I dunno how I felt about wooden chopsticks, though. It's definitely more practical, but did take away from the elegance). So just for the ambience TGP deserves more than 5 stars. 

TGP has a well curated menu. There is plenty to choose from, although vegetarian options maybe limited. They use fine quality ingredients like Jidori chicken, and mushrooms too fancy to google (kidding!). Also, there isn't sushi, ramen or yakitori for dinner. The portions are small, sharing size, but given Japanese cuisine is all about clean light and bright flavors, those elements alone will satisfy your appetite. The menu is divided into Cold and Hot; within the hot, light to heavy dishes.

The Sunomono: To dumb it down-fancy poke. To elevate it- fresh, cooling, and edible flowers. The moonfish is gorgeous and the coolness from the cucumber ironically punches through. 

Tebasaki gyoza: You haven't had chicken wings like this before. The inside is filled with shrimp. I don't know where the croissant is, in the filling or the crumb coat, but either way, stuffed wing like no other. Delicious, light, juicy and crunchy with an element of surprise. The sweet chile sauce seemed like the regular kind, I couldn't tell if it was house-made. 

Ikinari steak: Don't let the size fool you. It is rich and a very heavy dish. Comes out in a sizzling skillet. A huge dollop of miso brown butter, looks like gold and feels as rich, makes the steak outstanding. The skirt steak is cooked to perfection-  medium rare, tender juicy and a delicious char and asian flavor. The caramelized onions and corn really compliment the richness from the butter and sauce. Great fusion. 

Fried Tempura Chocolate Cake: I am not a big fan of the chewiness in mochi, so I went with the extreme opposite: texture bomb! This is a molten chocolate cake fried in tempura batter with dulce de leche sauce, with a side of ice cream, topped with sauteed puffed rice. So you have the ooey goeey, the crispy, crunchy, hot cold, solid and liquid.  Decadent, much? Most definitely. 
In spite of the multiple textures, it felt one note- very sweet. I wish they had some salt or citrus to cut the richness. 

Granted, I have not had enough Japanese food of this kind to compare so I may not be the best judge. I think the food is delicious and of high quality, but I just wasn't wowed by the flavors. It was an elevation of the quality and ingredients of the familiar asian flavors.

They have midday and lunch offerings too which would be great to try out. Prices are comparable, portions depending on the item maybe on the smaller side. 

The service is great. We actually went with the recommendations of our host who told us about the dishes. There is ample seating. 

The reason I was a little annoyed, I picked the wrong premier parking garage downtown (222 parking is the closest to TGP) and by the time I walked over to catch the midday menu, with ten minutes to spare till dinner at 5pm I couldn't order off it. So although the midday is till 5 it isn't. But I agree that's me being pesky. 

Nonetheless, next time. TGP is a great addition to downtown. The upscale Japanese food makes it very unique. And it is a very promising restaurant.

Waaay overhyped. Tapas style (they say). Seems like a poor excuse for TINY dishes. Had several (5) dishes and all mediocre. Stuffed chicken wings with shrimp toast was the best and that was just ok. Spent $100 and left hungry. Poor service. This is a definite no.

Excellent way to spend an hour and a half before a concert in downtown Nashvegas. I'm not ashamed to say that we needed to be schooled on how to read the menu and placing our order. Alex was a pro and recommend the "crowd pleasers" as well as his favorites and reasons why. He also asked us to pick two to three things at a time because as soon as the chef prepares each dish, it is brought to the table immediately. Thus, this was the pattern we created. Order eat, order eat, repeat. 

First up was the wedge salad with ginger dressing, fried oysters and the broccolini with bite sized shrimp. Just as we finished these scrumptious plates, we proceed with our next order of spicy crab noodles (be prepared to have a new addiction) and lobster dumplings. As our fork touched the desert plate on the last bite of a caramelized ginger creme brulee, we had come to realize that we experienced something truly special on a simple Tuesday night. From start to finish, The Green Pheasant impresses. Put it on your foodie bucket list pronto. 

Tip: before ordering, sit back with your wine or cocktail and watch what comes out of the kitchen. This is what we eventually did- telling Alex "we want that" or "that looks amazing, bring us that". The visual presentations were eye catching.

Everything on the menu is absolutely incredible, I suggest going with a large group so you can try as much as you can. The cauliflower and salmon were both outstanding, both recommended by the waiter who was knowledgeable and professional -- even sharing cultural context and traditions. 

Park in the deck and get it validated, and they have a coat check as well.

This place is top notch, with phenomenal service and such fantastic ambiance- how can you go elsewhere? All of the food looked and smelled amazing. I love how creative everything was.
I CANT STOP DAYDREAMING ABOUT THE FOOD. Hands down, best brunch experience of my life. I don't even like french toast usually and theres was by far the most delicious food thats ever entered my mouth. I am literally drooling while writing this.
The chicken and waffles were unreal and standout A++++. 
I love the "flinstones pushup-pop" drink so creative and clever.
Even the deviled eggs were the best I've personally ever had. They do everything right even when it comes to the music. It was super fun and such a great experience! Ignore any review thats not 4 stars because they must be delusional.

This place is INCREDIBLE! It's American food with a twist. Start with a drink. Get the Flintstone one. It's frozenish and I promise you won't regret it. Food rundown: Mussels in a French onion soup broth, 10/10. Tiramisu French toast, 10/10. Marinated fried chicken and waffles 10/10. But one of my faves has got to be the avocado toast, a perfect ten. To die for. My recommendation is to go out for brunch with some friends and split all of this deliciousness. You won't regret it. Oh and also, the staff knows what's up.

Outrageously overpriced for what it is. Insultingly so. It would be one thing if the cocktails warranted $12 but they simply do not. The bartender was very friendly so 2 stars for that but for that area and the subpar cocktails not even close to worth the price. Cannot speak to the food but definitely not a place I would go back to have a few drinks at.
Food here is AWESOME. Buffalo chicken egg rolls and lamb burger wrapped and prosciutto was unreal. Staff was really friendly. Great live music and hip atmosphere, definitely coming back!!

Came here on a Saturday afternoon for brunch with some friends. Let me just say, my experience was AMAZING. So, where should I begin?.... OH.. Let's start with the Tiramisu french toast. Now, I'm not one to order from the sweeter side of breakfast, but these were basically screaming at me from the menu. These little slices of heaven came out fast (which I always appreciate) and were DELICIOUS. My other friend ordered the CANNOLI PANCAKES. UNREAL - no surprise there. Aside from the incredible food, the staff is extremely friendly and attentive. The overall vibe of this place was just so upbeat and really set a great tone for the rest of my day in Philly. Can't wait to go back!

The best new bar in Philly. Amazing drink menu (and they taste as good as they sound), and delicious apps. The service is incredible and the bar is bustling with an energetic vibe that brings life to the quaint neighborhood. Thank you to Bar One for providing an atmosphere perfect for everyone!!! We can't to become regulars at Bar One!!!

Have been here twice with my boyfriend. We had great food and service both times. The menu is a good size and there is an airy atmosphere to the place. Mike was behind the bar during the Italian Festival when we stopped in, and he was quite a fella. He was a great example of what good service looks like. The lamb burger is awesome!!

Ekks, how hard is it to serve food that isn't raw. I hate giving out 1 star but anyplace that serves 2 separate items from the menu to the table that are inedible deserves it. Food sucks, drinks are wayyy overpriced, outside still looks as sh*tty as it was when it was the Wishing Well. I'm so confused as to why people think they can just put a new bar top in and expect it to succeed. Get a real chef and price drinks according to demographics and neighborhood. How f*cking hard is it to do that people?!

We are obsessed with this place. The bartenders are so friendly and the drinks taste amazing! The happy hour is exceptional. My friends and I have tasted many items on the menu. We love their mussels & flatbread!

Have been twice with my boyfriend and both times had great food and service. The menu is a good size and the place has a nice open airy atmosphere. Mike who was behind the bar is an awesome fella who went above and beyond to make sure we had a good time. The lamb burger was really really good. Check it out :)

If you are ever in the South Philly area be sure to stop by this new bar-restaurant! It is amazing! The staff is incredible & music is great! let's not forget the food an Italian take on bar food that is to die for! cannoli pancakes , tiramisu French toast , lamb burger, scampi mussels were all out of this world! They have a drink that has sorbet in it and tastes like a flint stones push up pop! I think we found our new spot for nights out!

Stop waiting to come here and just eat a meal here already! The food is simple and delicious and once you go it'll be easier to get over Wishing Well closing. 

Pesto deviled eggs OH MY. It's the perfect balance of everything you want in life. Creamy and milld yet somehow still packs a punch. Don't let any pine nuts go to waste on the plate either. 

I had the chicken cutlet sandwich. Perfect amount of spice. I wish they added more spread/sauce but the chicken was thin and breaded so that made up for it. Fries aren't really fries. More like less boring breakfast potatoes. They're whatever. 

The pappardelle with arugula and ragu somehow mastered the perfect balance between filling and light. Flavorful but not overpowering in the way arugula can be. 

Two thumbs up!
Best new bar in Philly! The menu and drinks are incredible and the staff is absolutely amazing - couldn't have had a better experience!

Writing this review before I've even left the restaurant because it's so amazing that I can't wait to do it! This place is a neighborhood gem and south philly is so lucky that it went in! Tonight was the grand opening and they passed around FREE appetizers! Who does that?! Amazing restaurants, that's who. The prosciutto lamb burger is to die for and the buffalo chicken pasta melts in your mouth. BarOne does a fantastic job at Italian bar food and their drinks and atmosphere make me want to come back every week. Bravo, delizioso, mangia!!!!!

$6.50 for a Kenzinger and the bartender didn't even know what it was. Probably one of the most highly ordered beers in Philadelphia other then PBR. $7.50 for a shot of Jim Beam. I'm Wishing this place Well, but how did you not learn from the previous businesses downfall. No one in the neighborhood wants to pay center city cocktail bar prices, for  standard corner bar ambience, and a pretty average food menu. Better make some aggressive changes quickly or your gonna have Bar None ;)

Was really excited to try bar one as I used to live less than a block away from the location. They did a really nice job renovating the bar, but I was not impressed by the food. We ordered four things:

cheesesteak pretzels: were basically pretzel nuggets from the pretzel factory with a cheesesteak sauce to dip in

tomato and mozzarella flatbread:The flatbread was over cooked and did not have much flavor

chicken cutlet sandwich: bread was stale (hint:sarcones is across the street- USE THEM)

buffalo chicken egg rolls:were actually really good and the best part of our meal

I hope these are just small problems for the restaurant to work out because it is a great location with a good concept for their restaurant, but right now the food needs improvement.
By far, the least attentive service I've ever received at a bar or restaurant in Philadelphia. Don't waste your time or your money.

First night.  Am here now.  Advertised free passed apps appetizers.  Corner table.  Ignored by EVERY server.  Other tables already had three apps!  If this is an indication of the future, FORGET IT!  And the music is too  loud!
Great neighborhood spot.  Very clean and well-maintained. Excellent pub grub. Fantastic burger. They always have Peroni on tap which works out just fine for me. Nice happy hour too.
Great spot to hang with friends! Awesome atmosphere and very friendly staff. Their cocktails are delicious! I would totally recommend Bar One to anyone looking for a new, good spot in S Philly

They renovated the space well. The lighting & atmosphere are much more inviting than they were in its previous iteration. The food was decent & plates were 1/2 off for happy hour. The server was attentive but didn't know anything about the beers on tap. And to read the draft list on the chalkboard we had to walk up to it bc it's unreadable from more than 3 ft away. They should consider putting drink prices on the menu. Overall, it's an ok new spot. I'll go back out of convenience but wouldn't seek it out.
Such a nice improvement from the previous bar (even though we loved and miss the old one). Menu is great.

I used to love coming to this bar when it was the wishing well and couldn't wait for Bar One to open. We were skeptical at first, but the drinks on the cocktail menu were fantastic and they had some decent local beers too. My boyfriend tried the old fashioned and the banana Jameson (Jameson soaked in banana and brown sugar!) and I tried the flinstones push pop and the spiked hot chocolate. The flinstones push pop had a scoop of berry sorbet, prosecco, and I believe a lavender liquor. It surprisingly wasn't too sweet and will definitely be a summertime favorite. The spiked hot chocolate was made from belgian chocolate and had a giant toasted marshmallow on top. It was honestly the best hot chocolate I have ever had and I definitely couldn't stop myself from slurping it down too fast! The old fashioned was pretty good too, and we definitely loved the banana Jameson. For the Irish whiskey lover it's a must try! Unfortunately we didn't try the food but we will definitely be back to try soon!
The dry-rub wings (that isn't the actual name) are the best wings I have ever had. Ever.
Stopped in here last night for a nightcap after a fabulous dinner at Market on Ninth . So nice just to be able to walk over .  Can't beat this little spot .  Perfect city night .

Went there with friends for a last minute dinner last night.  Was outstanding!  Service, food, ambiance.  I had the Short Rib pasta - PERFECT!  The only thing that keeps it from being 5 star is that I just wanted a small side salad - (like one I saw on the online menu, but not on the menu that night).  Wasn't possible to 'create' - oh, well.   I'll be back!  It's also a great place to eat alone at the bar.

Tonight was one of Bar One's opening nights offering free apps, 10/21. It was crowded but that's expected when a bar is giving out free food. I was able to try their chicken and waffle, buffalo chicken pasta, lamb slider, and pork and Buffalo chicken spring rolls. They were all fabulous. The food is really amazing here. Think Bar food with a classy twist. They had live music (one guy with a guitar playing covers) which had a good vibe setting the mood all night. Their draught beer list comprises mainly of local craft brews. They had 4 big screen TVs showing the sports game. This is a new age neighborhood bar that I will definitely come back to. Definitely glad to see a new bar at this corner.

Stop waiting to come here and just eat a meal here already! The food is simple and delicious and once you go it'll be easier to get over Wishing Well closing. 

Pesto deviled eggs OH MY. It's the perfect balance of everything you want in life. Creamy and milld yet somehow still packs a punch. Don't let any pine nuts go to waste on the plate either. 

I had the chicken cutlet sandwich. Perfect amount of spice. I wish they added more spread/sauce but the chicken was thin and breaded so that made up for it. Fries aren't really fries. More like less boring breakfast potatoes. They're whatever. UPDATE: Came back a week later and my cutlet sandwich had bacon in it and I got more than double the serving of fries. So good! But I took a star off bc I'm annoyed at lack of consistency. But damn it's good. 

The pappardelle with arugula and ragu somehow mastered the perfect balance between filling and light. Flavorful but not overpowering in the way arugula can be. 

Two thumbs up!

Ralph's Italian restaurant was totally booked, so we took a chance on Bar One, directly across 9th st. As we walked in, I loved the corner bar atmosphere.. staff was wonderful... then I looked at the menu. OMG my heart sank...... just weird for an Italian market eatery... my friend ordered Bucatini, at $16, they could have added a few more noodles..... it looked like a side dish... hopefully these guys didn't invest their life savings in this place

I went here on Saturday to try the free(!) brunch and LOVED it. The space is cozy without feeling dive-y and the artwork adds a character that is unmatched. We ordered the breakfast sandwich and tiramisu french toast and both were delicious. The nice selection of local draft beer and specialty cocktails will keep me coming back. Very excited to try the dinner menu!

My family and I were exploring the Italian market and realized we needed time out of the cold and lots of food. We were a group of 6 and most places had a long wait so we called and bar one could accommodate us right away. 

The brunch menu was definitely unique for a bar but did not disappoint. It seems everyone found something they liked. 

I personally had the kale caesar and tried someone else's avocado toast. They were both tasty although the toast was slightly burnt.

Overall service was okay but a few things were forgotten. Everyone seemed to like their meals but some of the portions were a little small depending on the dish. 

I'd definitely come back if I was in the area!
A great quite, dive. Typical south Philly at its finest. Food was on point and drinks were delicious too
Update 3: continued inconsistency with my beloved chicken cutlet sandwich. Was missing bacon and the bread was different. Still delicious but why change something that has been perfected?!

This bar is an awesome addition to the neighborhood! I came here for the grand opening and I wasn't disappointed. They passed out free delicious food to everyone and the beer selection was awesome (especially if you're a local beer lover like myself). Everyone seemed to be having a fun time and the live music was a great addition. I can definitely see myself coming back here in the future.
Cool bar, love the art work, the lamb burger and the inventive drinks. The space is good and I like the playfulness of the food. Hh is 1/2 off everything. Yeah I will be back.

Great neighborhood spot with outstanding mussels, great beer selection and excellent service. From the bartenders to the wait staff, everyone was friendly and attentive. We brought 2 kids and they had a blast. Best mussels we've had in a long time. I ordered beer mussels and my wife ordered scampi, both A+. My kids ordered mac & cheese which was prepared with homemade cavatelli, fantastic. Can't wait to go back!!

I live a block away and have always wanted a good bar to move into this space. Unfortunately, for one reason or another, they never work out and I won't be surprised if Bar One follows suit. 

The drink menu does not have prices. That should have been the biggest indicator. We ordered Kenzingers and Philly Pale Ales and the prices were absolutely ridiculous. Almost $7 for a single Kenzinger is unheard of, even in the most pretentious Center City bars, and this is South Philly. A shot of Jim Beam- $8. 

I'd rather walk a few blocks and go to literally any other bar then give this place my business again. 

Two stars go towards the half-way decent music and I can't deny that the food smelled pretty good. Can't imagine how overpriced that must be, though...

I have never had such delicious ice cream in my life. All natural with herbs chocolate cookie enhancements. The mint chocolate chip was the best I have ever had. The baklava had bits of sweetened philo, and the lavender enhanced cream brûlée had crunchy caramel throughout.

Stopped by for HH before the Sixers game and I must say they have great HH deals. Certain appetizers are half off and their house wines are $4 a glass. The bar wasn't that busy as most people trickled in as the game began, but its a good space for friends to hang out and watch the game. 

The stuffed long hots were the favorite. They are spicy and stuffed to the max with perfectly cooked sausage. 

The flatbread on the other hand was meh. Its not on your usual flatbread. What i thought was going to be a naan or pita like texture was more like a cracker. It's so thin and the toppings are piled high which made the "cracker" soft and soggy. The taste of the veggies needed salt too. 

Last thing we ordered was the beet salad. Slices of tomato, beets, and mozzarella cheese with a balsamic vinegar drizzle. I didn't think i'd he a huge beet fan, but these were good. 

If you get a chance to stop by for HH definitely hit up their drink specials and get the stuffed long hots!

Live in the neighborhood and it's much better than the bar prior. The staff is always attentive and nice. Food is pretty good, more bar style appetizers than real meals but nonetheless appetizing. They also make a great Moscow mule.

This is a fun bar I enjoy the casual but trendy atmosphere. It has a good energy. The food is very good. I think the beer is pricey some exceed $7 for the typical 14 oz glass. Tuesday night at 8 pm is trivia night. I recently had the pappardelle and it was delicious!

I recently went to Bar One for  my second time which was as good as the first. The first time I had the short rib potato skins which were to die for and the second time the flat bread. Well I have to say the food is second behind the great bartender Mike. He was working his butt off and still trying to give everyone the attention they deserved. I will be back!
Good spot for a drink to two with some pretty good menu items too. Awesome and friendly staff in a really nice updated and clean space.

Short rib potato skins and eggplant stack are awesome. Playlist of music in the bar thanks to Chris et. al is great. Atmosphere is fun and friendly and loud on week, but quieter on weeknights. Just as friendly and pleasant.

Recently moved into the neighborhood from center city and decided to try out Bar One. My husband and I have been here multiple occasions since we have moved in and have had a great experience every time. Some top notch things:
-Wonderful service! Mike and the other bartenders have been extremely attentive and friendly. 
-Dominic makes one of the best dirty martinis I have ever had...better than capital grille/delfriscos
-Great draft list - always rotating 
-A must go for brunch. We went today and enjoyed a juicy burger and the barones special. Home fries were crispy and the pancake was delicious! That paired with their homemade bloody hit the spot. 

Highly recommend for people to check out, especially if you are as picky as me. I've been to countless spots for brunch / cocktails and this is among the best in philly. A great mix of solid fresh food, tasty cocktails, and draft craft beer... they also have TVs which is must have with the philly sports run. 

Go sixers #ttp

Went back on a Tuesday and were able to get a table for 8 easily. We want Barone to be our neighborhood spot, but they're making it hard to do so. My friend ordered the mussels which were delicious, but when she asked for bread they told her they only give out bread for sandwiches. Bread. Sarcones is right across the street. 
We will come back because we understand that it's new and they may be working out the kinks still. Fingers crossed.

Went in on a Sunday evening and it was very quiet. Nice bar with approximately 15 tables for seating. We sat at the bar and the bartenders were super friendly. We ordered spiedini and sausage and pepper spring rolls. Both appetizers arrived hot and both were delicious. 
Next up was the papardelle with short ribs topped with Arugala.  Absolutely outstanding!!  Highly recommend Bar One aka Barone!  Can't wait to try the Brunch menu too.

Expensive and not the money.  Smug service and an overpriced breakfast sandwich with only one egg.  Wouldn't recommend, cute space in a nice neighborhood but better options for food considering the price.

Greta happy hour; 1/2 priced all drinks except premium liquor. We had the Flintstones push-up and Berry refreshing. I like the push-up pop, but I want it without the liqueur and I broke up the sorbet. I'm not sure how to capture the blood orange taste without the liqueur. Berry refreshing is very sweet and quenches your thirst. Careful you might drink it really fast, but if you go during happy hour you can two for the price of one so go ahead and drink up!
Oh and while you drink for 1/2 off at HH from 4-6 pm you can enjoyed 1/2 priced food and nightly specials too!!
Had really great experience this is my favorite place bartender was so attentive and knowledgeable my favorite drink was cucumber cooler We will be back again

Came here with a large group of friends after eating at the Italian market and was fairly underwhelmed. It was jumping with people and they were showing sports on the TV which made my husband happy but I found the atmosphere to be lackluster. Also there are two bathrooms but one was out of use which made for a very long line. One thing to note - - if you forget to bring wine to your BYOB in the Italian Market they sell it here!

This place is hands down my favorite happy hour go-to spot. The staff is super friendly/cool, and the food is delicious! Wide variety of yummy drinks for really good prices during happy hour. Definitely recommend!

There wasn't one dish that was anything short of phenomenal. You'll leave daydreaming of the cheesesteak mussels and lamb prosciutto burger for weeks.  Amazing drinks & atmosphere and friendly staff will make this your new go-to local bar in South Philly. Truly deserves SIX stars.

Pros: good food. Decent drinks. Nice neighborhood location. 

Cons: the two male bartenders that were on were totally inattentive. They were pretty boys so I am assuming that's the reason they were hired. Seemed like they kept catching their reflection in the mirror and were too busy to help. Had to literally call out to them if you needed anything. I would rather have slightly less attractive people who were good at their jobs than have the pretty boys in there ignore me. Service is everything, it doesn't matter how good the libations, the service is what brings people back or keeps them away.
Best bloody mary that I ever had. Very flavorful and spicy. Got try it

So glad something finally opened on this corner and what did looks so much better inside. The room has a great flow to it and the art on the walls compliments the place well.  The beer list was better than average and the menu was interesting.

Unfortunately there were some things that we really didn't like: the beer list has no prices nor does it specify what is on tap and what isn't. This made the final bill shocking as I didn't expect a PBC bottle to cost $8.99+. The tap list was illegible from the tables and the waiter suggested I go look at it to see what was on it. My flatbread came out over cooked and cold. Our waiter, while he tried and was nice, wasn't very knowledgeable about the food or beer.

2.5 stars overall. Going to give it one more chance since it's so convenient but hope to see some basic changes to tighten up the experience.
Good place for cocktails. Never eaten the food but looks good. The bartenders are friendly and it's usually easy to get a spot at the bar.

Bar One was truly outstanding, I cannot wait to come back!

I came here with some friends on a Saturday afternoon for brunch, and every element of this restaurant was perfect.  The service was impeccable.  The wait staff were so attentive, my glass was never empty.  We all had these delicious "Flintstones push pop" drinks , you must get one!  It is a mimosa with a scoop of sorbet, the ideal brunch drink to wash down all of the great food.  

The food was to die for.  The pickle back wings & waffles dish was my favorite.  The marinade and seasoning of the chicken is one of a kind, combined with the sweetness of the waffles, HELLO flavor explosion!  The avocado toast was also tops. Avocado, egg and Texas toast...perfection.  Another stand out was the Tiramisu French Toast, this is what actual dreams are made of.

I loved the overall ambiance of Bar One.  The art in the restaurant (and in the bathrooms) are really cool.  I wanted to take home one of the pieces hanging in the ladies room!  The music they were playing was awesome, everything from 90s alternative hits to Jay-Z.

Thank you Bar One for an amazing experience!!

It's was first time with friends.
I had a mezacalito was ok .
Eggplant mozzarella was awesome.
I had a pesto was ok bread was cold and hard.
Wasn't busy.
Bartender she was focused on only front guest.just looking us when we need anything.
Value was ok.
Experience was ok.

Nice neighborhood bar with good food and beer. They have sour monkey on tap which is one of my favorites! Huge plus. We got 2 apps and 2 entrees to split: pesto deviled eggs, Italian spring rolls, cavatelli, and the spicy chicken cutlet sandwich. Would skip the spring rolls (they kind of tasted like taquitos) but everything else was delicious! Cavatelli was the favorite for sure

Solid corner bar/restaurant in South Philly zone.  Owned by the family that owns Ralph's, across the street.  Beer is fresh and cold and service at the bar is friendly.  I sat at the bar and ate dinner and watched the Phillies on a sorta quiet Tuesday evening.  The food is good - not great - and not quite (but close!) to equal in taste/quality to the price.  I've been there a couple of times now and will definitely be back for a cold draft beer, friendly service and possibly, maybe, if-I'm-feeling-it... the food.  

Thanks!!

My girlfriend & I stopped in here one night before our reservation at Ralph's. We had an hour before dinner and decided to sit and have a drink here. Oddly enough, we checked their reviews and decided to give it a try. We got to talking with the bartender and she informed us that Ralph's owned Bar One. We glanced at the menu while we had our drinks and both agreed that we had to come back here. 

Fast forward a few months and we ended up back at Bar One for brunch. It was around 12:30 when we got there and I believe their brunch is 11-2:30 Then the kitchen closes for an hour and they start dinner at 3:30 PM. My girlfriend got Eggs Benedict that she really enjoyed. I ended up getting the cheesesteak omelette with their special wiz sauce on top. I didn't ask how they made their sauce but I suspect it's a mixture of wiz cheese and heavy cream; it was to die for. The entire meal was phenomenal. Their menu is also very eccentric which, as a foodie, I really enjoy. 

The staff is very friendly and informative. They also have a lot of drink specials. If you love Bloody Mary's you'll love it there. 

They seem to be a new bar so I wanted to make sure I gave them a good review to help spread the word. I definitely recommend Bar One and I'll be back.

I've been on a search for a good, under $20, pasta option for a little while. Bar One isn't it.

     Let's start with what it is, though. Can you go have a beer with your friends, and watch a little of the game? Yes, you definitely can. Do they have a beer list which comparable to other crafty, Philly spots? Yes, definitely. Is it crazy expensive, or crazy crowded? Nope...it's ostensibly a neighborhood bar.

     By no stretch of the imagination is it an Italian restaurant. Frankly, I'm not sure why Bar One even bothers to pretend it is such...perhaps the neighborhood, or proximity to the market...but at any rate, fine Italian cuisine it is not. Excited to try a new spot, stopped in on a brisk Friday in November and, ordered the cavatelli with Gorgonzola sauce and sausage. The most notable issue was that there was no sausage. Strike one. I could not identify the flavor of Gorgonzola in the pale grey sauce either. Let it be know that I love blue cheese, and a little goes a long way with said ingredient; it's a strong flavor. This, however, tasted more like a bland rue. The pasta itself was stuck together in clumps, which made me wonder how it was prepared...pasta doesn't do that in a sauté pan.  It was thoroughly underwhelming. 

    It's also worth mentioning the staff...or at least one bartender.  My gent was fine. He seemed to have a little trouble getting around, but was courteous enough, and managed my order with no issues. There was another, much ruder, gent who spent the evening - or at least the time that I was there - trying to recruit customers into belittling the other bartender (the one serving me). "Can you believe he has a degree in music?!?!...in MUSIC?", he asked me with his absurd Thomas Shelby haircut and manicured beard. "Who does that?!?", he continued in his effort to impress himself. I absolutely did not take the bait; nor did most of the other customers, in what I can only expect was everyone trying to extend common kindness to a man just trying to do his job. 

     Let's have a reality check here. 1. Publicly belittling others lacks both character and professionalism. Full stop. 2. I have a degree in music, and what has been (so far, thanks be to God) a lasting & rewarding career in the Arts. So, what was meant only as unnecessary posturing between staff members, deeply offended your clientele. I chose not to engage the argument, because that is in no way what I'm looking for in a dinning experience...an argument with an arrogant, yet poorly-informed bartender. The phrase "service industry" springs to mind...SERVICE...since we like to repeat ourselves. In conclusion, the food was edible but not good; yet it was the utter pretension of Mr. Shelby which will ensure that I will neither spend another singular dollar, nor recommend Bar One to any of my friends or readers. #Service

Vaguely remember coming here when the bar went by a different name, but glad to see it now operating as a solid happy hour spot.  Decent discounts on drinks, and a fairly varied food menu for happy hour, too.  Was here on a Tuesday, and was impressed by the solid crowd that came in for trivia, as well.

I love this bar!  I've been here twice, not during peak bar hours so I'm sure it's even more fun at night, but both times I've been I left wishing it was closer to where I live. 

The first I came here was for a quick drink to kill time before my reservation at Ralph's (which owns this bar).  The bartender was super informative, even giving us tips on what to order at Ralph's since it was my first time there as well, and the drink I had was delish. 

The second I went was this past Sunday for some food after bike riding. It was still brunch hours-I got the eggs benedict, my boyfriend got their special cheesesteak omelette, and we split the sausage and pepper spring rolls.  First off sausage and peppers is one of my very favorite foods so to see them offered in a unique way was really cool and they were really good. My eggs benedict was good too, but my boyfriends cheesesteak omelette, topped with their homemade wiz sauce, was beyond.  Both brunch entrees were served with spicy potatoes on the side which were tasty too. We had a different bartender this time and he was just as friendly and helpful as the one we had the first time. 

I've been here twice and I can't wait to go again.

This was my first and definitely last time. I would not recommend. I was being generous to give it 2 stars the only good thing is that it was clean. The waitress was very slow and inpatient. She was unprofessional in sharing her feelings about my disappointment to her co worker!!. I said that my wings were not done. They were hot wings and the skin was soft and wet as if it was not cooked hard enough it was still light no color besides the sauce. In addition, the other 2 orders that were brought out at the same time had the same complaint from 2 other tables. She frowned up her face and said a thermometer was stuck in them and they are done. When she took them back ,it took another hour before the new ones were brought
 The lamb burger was seasoned great but had toooo much salt. To top it off, the pasta had a peice if hair in it. We did not complain or say another word. We just packed up and left

Tonight was one of Bar One's opening night offering free apps, 10/21. It was crowded but that's expected when a bar is giving out free food. I was able to try their chicken and waffle, buffalo chicken pasta, lamb slider, and pork and Buffalo chicken spring rolls. They were all fabulous. The food is really amazing here. Think Bar food with a classy twist. They had live music (one guy with a guitar playing covers) which had a good vibe setting the mood all night. Their draught beer list comprises mainly of local craft brews. They had 4 big screen TVs showing the sports game. This is a new age neighborhood bar that I will definitely come back to. Definitely glad to see a new bar at this corner.

My mother and I went to the Italian Festival last Saturday, as I work in the area. There was plenty of food, family, music, and vendors. 

I wanted to try a new place with great food and service. As always, I read the reviews and pick my spots. So attempting to visit Bar One was not out of the ordinary. Well, as we walked through the festival, we saw a young lady passing out flyers to everyone. To my surprise, as when we got closer, she looked us in our faces, and turned around...mine you, there was no other individuals close to her to pass out the flyers, then us. At this point, I replied that maybe the business that she was representing had an exclusion policy. At that point, an older gentleman standing near her, heard the remark, apologized, and passed us a flyer. 

To my surprise, the flyer was from Bar One! At that point, we continued to walk to the end of the festival, and I was still interested in visiting Bar One. After reaching the end of the festival, we turned around and began to walk back. As we neared the Bar One vicinity, another gentleman was now passing out the flyers. As we approached closer to go near the front of the Bar One, the gentleman did not look at us to give a flyer to either. It was obvious that this second time within a 45 minute span was NOT an accident. We simply didn't fit the identity of their clientele. Point taken.

I understand Bar One's attempts to change the traditional Italian food into bar food but a lot of it didn't make sense. 

The Good - Let me say that I would RUN back for the french onion soup mussels, they were absolutely delicious and full of flavor. My favorite part were the french fries at the bottom of the bowl that were soaked with the french onion broth. 

The service! Each waiter was extremely attentive and nice, never had to ask for anything as it was already taken care for me.

The drinks were delicious as well! would come to drink rather than eat. 

The bad - the kale calamari salad. The calamari to salad ratio was way off, less calamari, more lettuce. The calamari it self was over salted and heavily coated. 

The Mafaldine pasta - was WAYYY under cooked, I like my pasta al dente but this was still raw. Also the pasta is way too large to have small pieces of shrimp and asparagus with. Again, this dish was over salted. 

In all, I would come back if improvements were made. I want to see this restaurant do well! Great location, and the place is cool.

Service was good, but the food was not.

As other reviewers have said, the burgers are not good here. I usually go for a mushroom burger but instead opted for their guacamole bacon burger. It's served on an onion ciabatta roll which did not add anything to the burger except for an overly hard texture, especially when paired with the dry burger patty. The guacamole could have used some more seasoning and the thick-cut bacon was okay. 

The fries that came with the burger were salty and soggy; my husband commented that they were likely old.
